00021 /**
00022  * \file  PgfFile.cpp
00023  * \brief
00024  *        Read \link file-format-pgf the PgfFile format \endlink for an overview.
00025  *        Read \link file-format-tsv the TsvFile docs \endlink more about TsvFile.
00026  */
00027 
00028 /**
00029 \page file-format-pgf File Format: PGF (NON-OFFICIAL-RELEASE)
00030 
00031 <center><b>DRAFT</b></center>
00032 
00033 The PGF (probe group file) provides information about what
00034 probes are contained within a probeset and information about
00035 the nature of the probes necessary for analysis.  The
00036 current PGF file format (version 1) is only specified for
00037 expression style probesets.
00038 
00039 The PGF file is based on version 2 of the \link file-format-tsv TSV file format \endlink.
00040 
00041 \section specifications Specifications
00042 
00043 - Required headers
00044   - chip_type: indicates the chip type (as stored in the CEL file) which the pgf file
00045     describes. Multiple chip_type headers may be present indicating the pgf file
00046     can be used with any one of the listed chip types.
00047   - lib_set_name: indicates the name of a collection of related library files for a given
00048     chip. For example, PGF and CLF files intended to be used together should have
00049     the same lib_set_name. Only a single lib_set_name is allowed.
00050   - lib_set_version: indicates the version of a collection of related library files for
00051     a given chip. For example, PGF and CLF files intended to be used together should have
00052     the same lib_set_version. Only a single lib_set_version is allowed.
00053   - pgf_format_version: currently the only documented and supported version is 1.0.
00054   - header0: indicates the values in the pgf file for the top level data (probeset level).
00055     A pgf file probeset level entry must contain probeset_id. This field must be unique
00056     over all the probeset_ids in the PGF file. Optional, but typical fields include
00057     type and probeset_name.
00058   - header1: the second level of data in the PGF file (atom level). An atom refers to
00059     a particular collection of probes that are interrogating the same position. For
00060     expression arrays an atom is usually a probe pair (pm and mm probe pair) from
00061     an array like HG-U133 Plus 2.0 or a single pm probe from an array like Human
00062     Exon 1.0 ST which does not contain mismatch probes. The atom level data must
00063     have an atom_id field. atom_ids are expected to be unique within the PGF file.
00064     In other words, atoms cannot be present in more than one probeset or present
00065     multiple times in any given probeset.
00066   - header2: the third level of data (probe level) contains information about
00067     a particular probe in a particular probeset. A probe may be present in more
00068     than one probeset, but it may only appear once in a given probeset. Required
00069     fields include probe_id and type. Optional, but typical fields include gc_count,
00070     probe_length, interrogation_position, and probe_sequence. A probe_id is not
00071     required to be unique within the PGF file -- ie that probe may be used in
00072     another probeset.
00073 - Optional headers
00074   - create_date: timestamp for when the file was created
00075   - guid: a unique identifier for the fileA
00076   - other headers may be present
00077 - Columns
00078   - per TSV format, order of columns is not guarateed
00079   - per TSV format, additional columns may be present
00080   - Probeset Level (level 0)
00081     - probeset_id (required): an integer id >= 0 which is unique over all the probeset_ids in the pgf file
00082     - type (optional): provides classification information for the probeset. See Type section.
00083     - probeset_name (optional)
00084   - Atom Level (level 1)
00085     - atom_id (required): an integer id >= 0 which is unique over all the atom_ids in the pgf file
00086     - type (optional): provides classification information for the atom. See Type section.
00087     - exon_position (optional): the position of the probe interrogation position relative to the target sequence
00088   - Probe Level (level 2)
00089     - probe_id (required): an integer id >= 0 which is a foreign key into the CLF file; a specific probe may be
00090       present in more than one probeset and as such is not guarateed to be unique in the PGF file. Also note that
00091       the additional columns of information at the probe level may be context dependent. So for example
00092       a particular probe could potentially be a PM probe in one probeset and an MM probe in another. While
00093       unlikely, this is a possibility.
00094     - type (required): provides classification information for the probe. See the Type section.
00095     - gc_count (optional): the number of G and C bases in the probe
00096     - probe_length (optional): the length of the probe
00097     - interrogation_position (optional): the interrogation position of the probe (typically 13 for 25-mer PM/MM probes)
00098     - probe_sequence (optional): the sequence of the probe on the array in from array surface to solution. For most
00099       standard Affymetrix arrays at this writing, this would be in a 3' to 5' direction. So for a sense target (st)
00100       probe (see the type field for the probe level) you would need to complement the sequence in this field before
00101       looking for matches to transcript sequences; for an antisense target (at) you would need to reverse this
00102       sequence.
00103 
00104 \section types Types
00105 
00106 Type columns in PGF files use the following string format to catagorize probesets, atoms, and probes:
00107 
00108 \verbatim
00109 simple_type:=[a-z0-9\_\-]+
00110 \endverbatim
00111 
00112 So an example simple type
00113 
00114 \verbatim
00115 pm
00116 mm
00117 st
00118 at
00119 control
00120 affx
00121 spike
00122 \endverbatim
00123 
00124 Furthermore, types can be nested. For example a particular spike may be from Affymetrix and is intended for
00125 use as a control. As a result you would combine the simple types to reflect this:
00126 
00127 \verbatim
00128 control->affx->spike
00129 \endverbatim
00130 
00131 Thus
00132 
00133 \verbatim
00134 nested_type:=(simple_type|nested_type)->(simple_type)
00135 \endverbatim
00136 
00137 Lastly, a given probeset, atom, or probe may belong to multiple independent types. For example, a probeset may be
00138 both a normalization control gene and part of the main design:
00139 
00140 \verbatim
00141 normgene->exon:main
00142 \endverbatim
00143 
00144 Thus
00145 
00146 \verbatim
00147 compound_type:=(simple_type|nested_type|compound_type):(simple_type|nested_type)
00148 \endverbatim
00149 
00150 Currently type values are not strongly enumerated. Values used in current commercial PGF files include:
00151 
00152 - Probeset Type:
00153     - main: probesets which are a part of the main design for which the array was designed
00154     - normgene->exon: probe sets against exon regions of a set of housekeeping genes
00155     - normgene->intron: probe sets against intron regions of a set of housekeeping genes
00156     - control->af&zwj;fx: standard Affymetrix spike control probeset (ie bacterial and polyA spikes)
00157     - control->bgp->antigenomic: antigenomic background probes
00158     - control->bgp->genomic: genomic background probes
00159     - control->spike->arabidopsis: arabidopsis spike control probesets
00160     - rescue->FLmRNA->unmapped: probesets against mRNA sequences which did not align to the genome
00161     - types removed in more recent PGF files:
00162         - control->QC: manufacturing control probesets
00163         - control->chip: internal control probesets used for gridding and other internal functions
00164 - Atom Type
00165     - (none)
00166 - Probe Type
00167     - pm: perfect match probe relative to intended target
00168     - mm: specific mismatch probe
00169     - st: a probe designed for sense target
00170     - at: a probe designed for antisense target
00171     - types removed in more recent PGF files:
00172         - blank: a blank feature
00173         - generic: an internal control feature
00174         - jumbo-checkerboard: an internal gridding feature
00175         - thermo: an internal control feature
00176         - trigrid: an internal gridding feature
00177 
00178 
00179 \section implementation Parsing and Writing
00180 
00181 The official C++ parser used by affy can be found in APT under
00182 sdk/file/TsvFile/PgfFile.h. When possible, parsing and
00183 writing of PGF files should be done using this code.
00184 
00185 \section notes Notes
00186 
00187 Specific applications may require extra/optional columns in
00188 the PGF file. Thus a valid PGF file may fail for a
00189 particular application or analysis algorithm because the
00190 information needed by that application and/or algorithm is
00191 not contained in the PGF file.
00192 
00193 It should be noted that there is no significance to the
00194 ordering of probes within atoms and atoms within probesets
00195 or even probesets within the PGF file.
00196 
00197 IDs do not have to be unique between different levels. In
00198 other words, the ID space for probeset_ids is separate from
00199 the ID space for atom_ids and probe_ids.
00200 
00201 \section pgfExample1 Example 1 -- Human Exon 1.0 ST PGF File Excerpt
00202 
00203 \verbatim
00204 #%chip_type=HuEx-1_0-st-v2
00205 #%chip_type=HuEx-1_0-st-v1
00206 #%chip_type=HuEx-1_0-st-ta1
00207 #%lib_set_name=HuEx-1_0-st
00208 #%lib_set_version=r2
00209 #%create_date=Tue Sep 19 15:18:05 PDT 2006
00210 #%guid=0000008635-1158704285-0183259307-0389325148-0127012107
00211 #%pgf_format_version=1.0
00212 #%header0=probeset_id type
00213 #%header1= atom_id
00214 #%header2=  probe_id type gc_count probe_length interrogation_position probe_sequence
00215 2590411 main
00216  1
00217   5402769 pm:st 12 25 13 CGAAGTTGTTCATTTCCCCGAAGAC
00218  2
00219   4684894 pm:st 13 25 13 ATGAGGTCACGACGGTAGGACTAAC
00220  3
00221   3869021 pm:st 11 25 13 AGGAGTACAGGGTAAGATATGGTCT
00222  4
00223   3774604 pm:st 14 25 13 CCCCGAAGACCCTAAGATGAGGTCA
00224 ...
00225 \endverbatim
00226 
00227 \section pgfExample2 Example 2 -- Human Genome U133 2.0 Plus PGF File Excerpt
00228 
00229 Here is a hypothetical example of a PGF file for an expression
00230 array with PM/MM pairs.
00231 
00232 \verbatim
00233 #%pgf_format_version=1.0
00234 #%chip_type=HG-U133_Plus_2
00235 #%lib_set_name=HG-U133_Plus_2
00236 #%lib_set_version=1
00237 #%create_date=Tue Mar 29 16:48:05 2005
00238 #%header0=probeset_id type probeset_name
00239 #%header1= atom_id
00240 #%header2=  probe_id type gc_count probe_length interrogation_position probe_sequence exon_position
00241 1354897  204339_s_at
00242  1354898
00243   1221821 pm:target->at 13 25 13 ACAACGACCGTTCCGGAATCGACAT 1703
00244   1222985 mm:target->at 13 25 13 ACAACGACCGTTGCGGAATCGACAT 1703
00245  1354899
00246   788881 pm:target->at 8 25 13 TTACATCATACTTTCTTGTCTCTAG 1355
00247   790045 mm:target->at 8 25 13 TTACATCATACTATCTTGTCTCTAG 1355
00248  1354900
00249   516645 pm:target->at 12 25 13 GAATCTTATCACGAGTTCCACCTCC 1518
00250   517809 mm:target->at 12 25 13 GAATCTTATCACCAGTTCCACCTCC 1518
00251  1354901
00252   736948 pm:target->at 12 25 13 GAGTTCCCTCGATTCCATAAACGAG 1543
00253 \endverbatim

00255 \section related Related Pages
00256 
00257 - <a href="./file-format-tsv-notes.html">TsvFile Design Notes</a>
00258 - <a href="./file-format-tsv.html">TSV File Format</a>
00259 
00260 \section pgf_dev_notes Developer Notes
00261 
00262 - If you are defining a file format which is based on
00263   TsvFile, use this as an example.
00264 - PgfFile is not subclassed as we dont want it to inherit
00265   methods from TsvFile.  This prevents calling a method
00266   by accident.
00267 - m_tsv is a member so it appears when a PgfFile is made.
00268   (ie: minus messy memory management)
00269 - We make "tsv" public so if the programmer
00270   wants to work with the underlying tsv object may do so.
00271 
00272 */
00273 
00274 #include "file/TsvFile/PgfFile.h"
00275 
00276 /// This defines an object which has fields and some methods
00277 /// to make working with PGF files a snap.  Basicly we define
00278 /// user friendly method which map to TsvFile mothods.
00279 namespace affx
00280 {
00281 PgfFile::PgfFile()
00282 {
00283   probeset_id = -1;
00284   probeset_type = "";
00285   probeset_name = "";
00286   atom_id = -1;
00287   probe_id = -1;
00288   probe_type = "";
00289   gc_count = -1;
00290   probe_length = -1;
00291   interrogation_position = -1;
00292   probe_sequence = "";
00293   makePgfBindings();
00294 }
00295 
00296 /// @brief     Destroy a PgfFile object
00297 PgfFile::~PgfFile()
00298 {
00299 }
00300 
00301 /// @brief     Make the normal bindings to the standard PGF slots
00302 void PgfFile::makePgfBindings()
00303 {
00304   // start afresh
00305   m_tsv.unbindAll();
00306   //#%header0=
00307   m_tsv.bind(0, "probeset_id", &probeset_id, TSV_BIND_REQUIRED);
00308   m_tsv.bind(0, "type", &probeset_type);
00309   m_tsv.bind(0, "probeset_name", &probeset_name);
00310   //#%header1="
00311   m_tsv.bind(1, "atom_id", &atom_id, TSV_BIND_REQUIRED);
00312   //#%header2=
00313   m_tsv.bind(2, "probe_id", &probe_id, TSV_BIND_REQUIRED);
00314   m_tsv.bind(2, "type", &probe_type);
00315   m_tsv.bind(2, "gc_count", &gc_count);
00316   m_tsv.bind(2, "probe_length", &probe_length);
00317   m_tsv.bind(2, "interrogation_position", &interrogation_position);
00318   m_tsv.bind(2, "probe_sequence", &probe_sequence);
00319   // this seems to be unused...
00320   // m_tsv.bind(2,"exon_position",&exon_position);
00321 }
00322 /// @brief     Open a PGF file
00323 /// @param     filename the pathname of the file
00324 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00325 int PgfFile::open(const std::string& filename)
00326 {
00327   std::string val;
00328   int rc = m_tsv.open(filename);
00329   if (rc == TSV_OK) {
00330     int rv = m_tsv.getHeader("pgf_format_version", val);
00331     Err::check(rv == TSV_OK, "No pgf_format_version header in pgf file");
00332     Err::check(val.compare("1.0") == 0, "Unable to handle pgf file format");
00333   }
00334   return rc;
00335 }
00336 /// @brief     start the write of a PGF file.
00337 /// @param     filename
00338 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00339 int PgfFile::write(const std::string& filename)
00340 {
00341   return m_tsv.writeTsv(filename);
00342 }
00343 /// @brief     Close a PGF file
00344 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00345 int PgfFile::close()
00346 {
00347   return m_tsv.close();
00348 }
00349 /// @brief     Rewind back to the start of the PGF data
00350 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00351 int PgfFile::rewind()
00352 {
00353   return m_tsv.rewind();
00354 }
00355 /// @brief     Skip to the next probeset
00356 /// @return    TSV_LEVEL_LAST when out of probesets
00357 int PgfFile::next_probeset()
00358 {
00359   return m_tsv.nextLevel(0);
00360 }
00361 /// @brief     Skip to the next atom, but not beyond
00362 /// @return    TSV_LEVEL_LAST when out of atoms
00363 int PgfFile::next_atom()
00364 {
00365   return m_tsv.nextLevel(1);
00366 }
00367 /// @brief     Skip to the next probe, but not beyond
00368 /// @return    TSV_LEVEL_LAST when out of probes
00369 int PgfFile::next_probe()
00370 {
00371   return m_tsv.nextLevel(2);
00372 }
00373 /// @brief     Define a tsv file as a PGF file.
00374 /// @param     tsv       pointer to tsv to define
00375 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00376 int PgfFile::defineFilePgf(TsvFile* tsv)
00377 {
00378   Err::check(tsv != NULL, "affx::PgfFile - no tsv file provided to defineFilePgf");
00379   // note embedded "\t"s and "\n"s.
00380   return tsv->defineFile("probeset_id\ttype\tprobeset_name\n"
00381                          "atom_id\n"
00382                          "probe_id\ttype\tgc_count\tprobe_length\t" // line break for length.
00383                          "interrogation_position\tprobe_sequence\texon_position\n");
00384 }
00385 /// @brief     Define this file as a pgf file
00386 /// @return    tsv_return_t
00387 int PgfFile::defineFilePgf()
00388 {
00389   return defineFilePgf(&m_tsv);
00390 }
00391 
00392 /// @brief     Get a ptr for SWIG
00393 /// @return    a pointer to the internal TSV file object
00394 affx::TsvFile* PgfFile::tsv_ptr()
00395 {
00396   return &m_tsv;
00397 }
00398 
00399 
00400 };
